DIV1.P: THE NOTE OF HAND; OR, TRIP to NEWMARKET.
THE NOTE OF HAND; OR, TRIP to NEWMARKET.
AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL in DRURY-LANE.

Q.L: Nosse omnia haec salus est adolescentulis.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, the Corner of the Adelphi, in the Strand.

LG.L: OH such a sight! I've been upon the course,
And he may talk his nonsense tell he's hoarse:
What matters an old Canterbury story?
Upon my soul Newmarket's in its glory.
Such galloping, such gambling and such betting,
Such capering, such cutting and curvetting!
Oh, such a world of bothering and of noise,
So many Cambridge hacks and College boys:
Then there is such a riot and a rattle
With lists of terrible, terrible high-bred cattle;
List of the sporting Ladies, Sir?—O Lord,
This foolish poet's no where, take my word.
He's jaded at two heats, as I'm alive,
'Tis well it's out of rule to start for five.
What signifies his farce! 'tis all a jest;
Upon my soul Firetail's a lovely beast—
So sleak, so trim, so slender and so thin,
They lead him out and then they lead him in.
Oh, if that Roman fellow now was there,
(What was his name?) that made his horse Lord May'r;
He might have choice and plenty, a whole stud
Of Senators and Consuls, thorough blood.
What neighing after one another's spouses,
What snorting and what kicking in both houses!
Shake but the sieve, as sure as I am born,
There's none amongst 'em, but wou'd come to corn.
Why such a hair-brain'd spark might think it wit
To turn his stable loose into the pit:
Long-tail and bob-tail, blacks and sprightly bays;
And filthy duns and old flea-bitten greys,
Young high-bred fillies, and fine dappled mares,
And braying crities with long pricking ears:
Stand by your poet, Sirs; and keep your places,
You'll get no harm at his Newmarket Races.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.

ROW.CELL: Uncle to Rivers, conceal'd under the name of Sunderland.

DIV1.P: Grooms, Jockies, Lacqueys, Waiters, and others.

DIV1.HEAD: THE NOTE OF HAND; OR, TRIP to NEWMARKET.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A Gaming-House. Rivers is discover'd asleep on a couch; dice boxes on the table, with candles nearly burnt out; the floor spread with cards, and his hat and sword lying upon it: the room in great disorder. Sunderland enters; and, after contemplating him sometime, speaks.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: SO, so! broad noon and your night just begun—what drudgery it is to be a gamester! a watch∣man's dog enjoys more quiet. Yes, you may turn and toss, young Sir, there's no composure in that sleep of your's: Oh! that your brother bubbles, some of the noble jockies, wou'd look in, and profit by the scene! will no earthquake swallow down Newmarket? Well, I shall not molest you, sleep while you can, and either wake to a repent∣ance of your follies, or never wake again.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Who's there? What's that? Where am I? Sun∣derland! I've dropt asleep; why, what's o'clock? Oh, now I recollect it all. Fool, fool, what have I done?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: So, Mr. Rivers, you've not been in bed.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: No, Sir, you find me as you left me.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: That's four hours ago; I left you before eight, and 'tis now turn'd of twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Indeed! You're a successful player, Mr. Sun∣derland.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: As it happens;—I believe I won a trifle of you last night.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: A trifle!

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: What are a few hundreds, or call 'em thousands? what are they? a feather to your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Be not deceiv'd; the sum I stand indebted to you breaks up my whole estate; I shou'd not mention difficulties justly affecting myself, but as my lands lie principally in Ireland, 'twill ask some patience on your part.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Take your time, Mr. Rivers; my occasions do not press; take your own time; or if you like it better take your revenge. (pointing to the table.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P:
No, may this hand of mine, that shakes that
cursed box, drop from my wrist before it sets a sin∣gle guinea on a cast again.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Can you be serious? what was fortune doing, when she gave me such success? I'm sorry it disturbs you—break up your estate! it must not be.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You must excuse me, Sir; if you are paid, I trust you'll leave the mode of it to me.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: If I mistake not, Mr. Rivers, you've an uncle daily expected from India.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I hear too he has made a considerable fortune: spare your estate and give me a post-obit upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Not for the world;—you totally mistake me.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Nay, if you regard such scruples, give me leave to say you play but half the game: with the professors of the art the lives of uncles, sathers, dowagers and aunts, are handed over with as much indifference as the cattle in their stables. Either forswear your scruples or the dice. What! no doubt you are your uncle's heir.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Certainly not. How can I, who have lost my fortune by my folly, expect that he will give me his, who gain'd it by his industry!

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P:
His principle I see is sound. (aside.) Well, I
shall urge this point no further—there is yet an∣other hope, another reprieve for your estate.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: A wife, a fond generous woman, with a season∣able recruit of cash: such may be found.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Nay, let me tell you, such a one is found—peruse that note. (giving him a note.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Mrs. Cheveley! is it possible? she at Newmarket!

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: She: and what think you but an uncontroulable attachment brought her hither, to be the talk and may game of the place?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Who dares to talk about her?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I do;—every man who has a tongue;—all the grooms and lacqueys in Newmarket:—why the sun is not more clear than that she dotes upon you to distraction—by my soul, she's dying for you.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I cannot be a rascal;—I am not fit for the society of virtue;—besides she has now such advantages in point of fortune—

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: That there's positively no resisting the temptation.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Pardon me; the world shall never say I married upon mercenry views▪

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: What better excuse can the world give for your marrying at all? but we are interrupted—That note, I suppose, contains a summons: we shall meet again. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: REVELL enters, attended by Grooms, Jockies, and others equipt for the course. RIVERS retires to the back scene, and sits down; the Waitrs set the room in order.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Tom Epping, Tom!

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: Your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: When do you lead out?

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: In half an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Harkee, have you the match-list? let me see—Burford, York, Newmarket;—March, April, October—'tis a respectable catalogue:—one, two, three—Oh! they are number'd I see, in all thirty∣seven single matches, sweepstakes and plates ex∣cepted.

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: I believe, your honour, that's about the tot of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: What have we got for to-day? Waiter, make some cosfee.—Ah, Rivers, are you there?—What matches stand for this morning, I say?

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: Why there is first Lord Catchweight's Petit Maitre against your honour's Joan of Are, Row∣ley's mile, five hundred of a side.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: A hollow thing, he'll pay half forfeit—Where are you going, Frank? (to Rivers) What ails you?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Nothing: let me pass.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Is the man hypochondriac? Has repentance at∣tack'd you in the similitude of a rich young widow?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Pooh! (Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Ridiculous! Well, Tom, go on; there's an∣other match I think.

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; your gelding Supervisor against Sir Harry Handicap's Belzebub.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: True, Supervisor; he's a craving horse; he'll run it through; you must go off at score with Supervisor.

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: Hng him; my life upon't, he'll prove a rogue: Belzebub is the favourite with all the quality in this place.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Well, well! but why should Supervisor prove a rogue?

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: Because, an please your honour, there's bad blood in his pedigree: is not he full brother to Matthew Mite, out of Nabob's Dam Scullion? and did your honour ever know a colt of Scul∣lion's, but what train'd for all the world like a hackney?

SP.SPEAKER: SECRETARY.
SP.P: Will your honour be pleased to give attention to this dispatch? the messenger is waiting, and 'tis a matter of the last consequence to the peace and interest of Great Britain.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Time enough; I'll think of the interest of Great Britain presently—Harkee, has Jack Sweatem come down yet to seven stone?

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: Please your honour, he was within three pounds six ounces this very morning: the lad is here; come hither, Jack; he is in as promising a con∣sumption as heart can wish.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Very well: how many waistcoats have you on, Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: JOCKEY.
SP.P: Eight, an please your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Go your ways, you may ride Lady Betty on Friday, she's match'd from the ditch-in against Colonel Mac Swiney's Fortune-Hunter, is she not?

SP.SPEAKER: EPPING.
SP.P: She is; no crossing—that should be barred in all heats with these young cattle.

SP.SPEAKER: SECRETARY.
SP.P: I pray you, Sir, take some consideration of this business, the council meets on Friday, your opinion is expected; consider the responsibility of your office.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Consider the responsibility of my betts, Mr. Pemberton—Issachar, which way look your bar∣gains in the Alley; is war or peace your game?

SP.SPEAKER: ISSACHAR.
SP.P: War, war; loss of credit; fall of stocks; heavy, heavy is the word with me: debt upon debt; tax upon tax; long arrears and short pay∣ments; other people's loss is my gain—so lies my account.

SP.SPEAKER: SECRETARY.
SP.P: Good Sir, be more serious; the messenger must be dispatch'd; in my apprehension, this be∣fore you is the nicest question for political dis∣cussion I have met since I knew business.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Well, well! scratch out the copy of a letter; state the matter doubtfully; give no opinion; leave a blank for my name, and I'll sign the letter; trifles are soon dispatch'd; come let's to business. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: An Inn Room, SAPLING and FRAN∣CIS the Waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Well, Francis! well, Boy!—so you shouldn▪t ha' known me again, hey?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Not I, upon my soul, Master Sapling; I shou'd never have taken such a brave spark as you are for our Exciseman's son, and a Hackney Writer's clerk.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Hackney Writer, poh! I only amuse myself now and then, as other young gentlemen do, with copying a skin of parchment, nothing more: but what d'ye think o'me, Francis; am I the thing? do I look knowing, hey, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Deep, deep!

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: That's well; that's well—d'ye like my nab? had it of 'Squire Revell's hatter: smoke the spurs, Francis; honest Moore of Poland-street—studied Darnley's prints for a Turf-Macaroni—was two hours tying my neckloth with the true Tyburn knot.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Ah, Master Sapling, you may have that done for you in a quarter of the time.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Had some thoughts of sitting to Stubbs for my picture, with a nag in the back ground, for I can't ride you must know, only this journey lick'd so deep: came down in a phaeton, boy; ay, and should have brought Fanny with me; don't you know Fanny Slattern?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Not I, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: No! a charming girl; she would have been happy to have seen Newmarket.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Why didn't you bring her, then?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Practising my phaeton in Moor-fields, drove over a pawn-broker's stall, threw poor Fanny out and dislocated her collar bone, the day before I came away.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Well, Sir; I must about my business; you'll excuse me; the room is your's for the rest of the meeting—[Bar bell.]—who calls? coming, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: This is life, dammee! but the course I've taken to come at it, may be death. Well, the present's all, here am I at Newmarket with an equipage at command, and a room to myself; better than sitting half a dozen at a desk in Pippin Alley: phaw 'tis quite another thing—methinks 'tis a very snug, convenient apartment this of mine; quite private, and free from noise or interruption.
SP.STAGE: (A violent noise is heard without, and the door is burst open, and O'CONNOR MAC CORMUCK, enters the room.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Oh! is it there that you are? wouldn't it ha' been a deal easier now to have open'd the door, than put me to all this trouble of coming in without it?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Mercy on me, what a fright am I in! would I were back again in Pippin Alley!

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: I suppose you belong to this house, young man.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: What shall I say? to this room I do, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay, ay! to this house, or this room, 'tis all one for that, d'ye see: and why then, if you be∣long to this room, did you keep me standing in the yard, with my beast in my hand, and not shew us both into a chamber? answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Ahem! where is my heart fallen to?—Sir, un∣der favour I conceive, Sir, 'tis not my business to provide for either you or your beast.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: What is your business then, may I ask?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: I follow no business, Sir; I'm a gentleman—I begin to be tired of the title. (aside▪

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: A gentleman! I should as soon take your mo∣ther for one; but it may be so; you may be a gentleman, and that may be the habit of a gen∣tleman, and that bush at your back may be all of your own growth; but you'll excuse me, Sir;—Paddy, bring in my luggage.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Hey-day! I must speak now or never—Sir, pray, Sir, understand me right; this is extraor∣dinary behaviour—what is it you are doing?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Nothing in this life, my dear, but bestowing upon you the society of my portmanteau; securing my effects: where can they be so safe as in a gentleman's company?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: If your back was turned, perhaps, I cou'd dis∣pose of them. (aside.) Pray, allow me to ask whom I am obliged to for this visit?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Is it my name you wou'd know?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: If it is your pleasure to tell it.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: With all the readiness in life; you shall know, Sir, my name is one Mr. O'Connor Mac Cormuck, of Shallinoghrag, in the county of Antrim; that is my name, Sir, and has been so, for aught that I can tell, ever since the confusion of tongues at the Tower of Babel.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: 'Twas enough to breed a confusion there, or any where else.—Well, Mr.—(I shall never learn his name) you're moving forwards, I suppose;—you're on the road;—your portmanteau shall be welcome to a place in my room while you stay. You're for a mutton chop I reckon, and away.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: There's your mistake, my dear; your heads in this place, I perceive, are all upon the gallop; but I'm staying here a piece.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: The devil you are!

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: I've a small little bit of a lease, d'ye observe me, under one Mr. Rivers, of Castle-Rivers, who I'm told is in this place gambling up and down, so I wou'd fain have him fill it up, d'ye see; and in the meantime I'd let him into the secret a little how his affairs stand, or I shou'd rather say tum∣ble down, in the county of Antrim.—Oh, there's been precious doings with the Hearts of Steel; blood and 'oons, man alive, 'twou'd make all your bowels quake in your body only to hear of it.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, don't put yourself to the trouble of telling it then.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: No, No: I'll save it to divert you with as we lie asleep in the same chamber at night.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: In the same chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay; did you think I was to sleep in the stable with my beast.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: No, but I hope you'll find some other room more convenient than this.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Faith, Sir, contentment's all; I mean to look no further.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: I find you misunderstand me, Sir:—you must excuse me;—I am hear by myself; I wish to be private.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: And that is the reason you come to a public place.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: But the chamber is mine;—I've hir'd it for a week.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Then you may very well spare it for a day.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: I give a guinea a night for the bed.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Keep it to yourself; I can sit up for half the money.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Gentlemen, the ordinary is erved; the guests are sitting down, and if you don't make haste you'll be cut out of commons.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Then upon my soul, all ceremony cases with me;—by your leave, Sir. (to Sapling.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: O Francis, I'm undone! this blundering Irish∣man, has run me down as a West-country barge wou'd a wherry. It's impossible to go to dinner uch a figure.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Ah, Master Sapling, there's no being a gentle∣man for nothing. Come along. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I took him in the very crisis of his fate; flush'd with his morning's sport, and warm with company and wine: fortune conspir'd with the opportunity; our play ran deep; he with the impatience of a losing gamester press'd his evil luck, and when the morning arose, it found him wearied out with watching and stript of half his fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Poor Rivers!

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: It was a brain-blow; it has wrung him to the quick:—I think I may depend upon his reforma∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: I think you may;—h e has none of the vices of his trade about him; he is not covetous, he is not cruel; it is fashion which corrupted Mr. Rivers; nature never meant to waste so good a heart upon a gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I am blest to hear you say so, and I hope that your forgiveness and acceptance of a repenting prodigal will coincide with mine;—he honourably loves you; I have prob'd his feelings, under this concealment, and find both principle and affec∣tion sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Has he no suspicion, Mr. Rivers, of your being his Uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: None: our long separation, and the precautions I have taken obviate that:—nay, I touch'd him upon his expectations of my fortune, and sug∣gested the expedient of a post-obit in satisfaction of his gaming debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: But he rejected it—

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: With scorn, and honourably stated it as an event he justly despaired of; in the same stile he spoke of his pretensions to your favour; and 'tis there that he is wounded deepest.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Mr. Rivers, Madam, desires leave-to pay his respects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Admit him, by all means; I shall be happy to see Mr. Rivers.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: I cou'd have told him that before I deliver'd his message. (aside.) [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Madam, good morning to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Are you going, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Assuredly:—I wou'd not rob my nephew of an interview, on the success of which so much of my own happiness depends. Now love and pity touch your heart! Farewell. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Touch did he say? they occupy it wholly,

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Mr. Rivers. [Exit Ser.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: This is an unexpected happiness—Newmarket is the last place I shou'd look for Mrs. Cheveley in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: True, 'tis a scene above my sphere; but I have edisied so much by the discourse of grooms and jockies, that I'm charm'd with my advances in so fashionable a science.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Come, you despise the science and every one who studies it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: You shall excuse me, I can think lightly of no studies which may at all advance me in the con∣sideration of Mr. Rivers.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I feel your reproof, and I deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: No, I respect your taste; where is the nation that can exhibit such a meeting? 'Tis an English∣man's prerogative to keep an animal whole months in training, for the operation of a few minutes;—then 'tis a sight of such complacency to see the senators and nobles of the realm, in council on the pedigree of a race horse, or whispering in the ear of a stable boy upon the merit of reducing himself to seven stone eight.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Go on, you cannot execrate the business more than I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Indeed! what must the science be, which its professors hold in such abomination? But, perhaps, your's is only the spleen of a moment, a lover's quarrel taken up upon the spur of some new dis∣appointment: you'll soon be reconcil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Never: there may be injuries too deep for re∣conciliation; I and my follies can keep terms no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Part then; 'twill be a joyful separation.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, but 'tis a sorry compliment, when a man pays his addresses to reason, only because he's tir'd of his connections with folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: A convert upon experience, is the fastest friend either reason or virtue can acquire.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: But the world will have its share in our atten∣tions, regulate them how we will; nay, there are other objects I have lost, which all the charms of reason or of virtue never can replace.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Humph! what are they?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: That is a question, which to you of all the world I never ought to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P:
That's hard; but are they lost? those objects which you say you hold so dear, are you assur'd
that they are lost? for my part, it is principle not circumstance which weighs with me:—I can have pity for a losing gamester, but I shudder at the man who fattens on the agonies of the unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: O, Madam, I must leave you; I shall do some act to damn my honour, and in an unguarded moment forfeit that pity which is all that I deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: He's gone, and that abrupt departure tells me all that I wou'd wish to know:—his silence his distress, endears him to me:—honour ties his tongue, but mine is free. Reserve and cold sus∣picion, I have done with you; let the more cau∣tious part of my sex take you to their bosoms altogether; mine was made for confidence and love. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE,
DIV3.STAGE: MAC CORMUCK with SPAVIN, DIPP, and PUTTY, sitting round a card-table. They rise.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Hear me, I say, once for all, hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: ALL.
SP.P: Hear him! hear him!

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay, and if you remember him too, it may be all the better for some of you.

SP.SPEAKER: ALL.
SP.P: Hear him! hear him!

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: What is it all you're about? if it is game of me you are making, by the scull of my father, you couldn't have pitch'd upon a worse person in the three kingdoms than O'Connor Mac Cormuck! as to your gambling and galloping phrases, d'ye see, I know nothing of the matter: your Creeping Molly's, your Catch-me and Kiss-me, and Sweet∣est-when-naked, and all the foolish names you put upon your cattle, I've no head for such trumpery; but I've a heart, d'ye mind me, that will not bear an insult either to myself or my country.

SP.SPEAKER: DIPP.
SP.P: You mistake, Sir, no body here means to af∣front you, or your country.

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: Let me see who dare; am not I your friend?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Truly, Sir, I am not apt to make such hasty friendships; however, if you are determined to be my friend, be friend enough to tell me who, and what you are?

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: My name is Spavin, and I deal in horses: I am well known at Newmarket; I generally keep a good nag under me; when a man is on the win∣ning side, it is convenient for collecting betts—

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay, or for running away from 'em when yon lose, Mr. Spavin—Now, gentlemen, for you.

SP.SPEAKER: DIPP.
SP.P: Dipp is my name; while I had any business I was a tallow-chandler, and my neighbour Putty here, was once a glazier: trade was dead, our stock hung on hand, so the Gazette hook'd us both in, and disposed of it for s without further trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: So from selling candles by the pound, Master Dipp, you came to sell 'em by the inch; a very valuable set of acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: Well, if you've a stomach for your revenge, I'll stand to my partner for another rubber.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Yes, but you'll excuse me, if I tell you there's a small mistake in your play.

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: How so, Sir, what mistake?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Why, when you are my partner in the game, d'ye see, you are a little apt to mistake which side you are to play upon: so, gentlemen, I don't chuse to have any thing more to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: PUTTY.
SP.P: Yes, but you'll chuse to pay us our winnings, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: You can't deny the gentlemen that justice; you see I've paid my money.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: But perhaps, friend, I may not always chuse to follow your example. Come hither, waiter, who are these persons I▪ve been playing with?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCI.
SP.P: Sir, I don't know, Sir—I believe they're gen∣tlemen of the turf; sporting gentlemen, I be∣lieve.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Sporting gentlemen, you believe—gentlemen of the turf; what sort of gentlemen are they?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Come a little nearer, Sir—'tis not for the credit of the house, that strangers should be pillag'd at this rate. These fellows are gamblers, black-legs, sharpers—you conceive me; you need not say, I told you so.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Trust me for that. Stand further off. Your most obedient, gentlemen sportsmen; now I un∣derstand you and your profession, I have an equal honour for both: you are an ornament to your country, and I dare say your sweet persons will beautify the highways and hedges from the top of a gibbet before you're much older. Why, you abominable ragamuffins, did you think to trick a poor Irish gentleman out of his money by signs and signals; scratching your noses and stroking your ears? By my soul, 'twill serve you right to cut 'em from your heads. (draws his hanger.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Sir; what are you about?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Only going to rub the marks off their faces, that they may play fairer for the future—

SP.SPEAKER: DIPP.
SP.P: Help, help; let's come out, you shall pay for this, Master Francis.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Say you so, Sirrah, then down with the money to enable him; down with the five pieces you won of me, rascals, or I'll cut 'em out of your skins; put 'em down I say on the table, and troop.

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: This is downright robbery; the money was won fairly, and more too, if you had the honesty to pay it.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P:
Honesty, fellow! (catching hold of him) you are the worst knave of the three; they only cheated
me; you was my partner and cheated me and yourself into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: DIPP.
SP.P: Come make no more words about it; there's your paltry five guineas; now let us out.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Count 'em, my lad, are they in full?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: They are.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: And good ones?—now away! begone!

SP.SPEAKER: PUTTY.
SP.P: A plague upon it, say I, what a foolish figure we cut!

SP.SPEAKER: DIPP.
SP.P: We won it like knaves, and we refund it like fools.

SP.SPEAKER: SPAVIN.
SP.P: Get you gone, for a couple of cowards; I ne∣ver would have given it up. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Now, my lad, take up the money, you have earn'd it, keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, Sir, what I did was out of principle, the money is your own.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P:
That cannot be, for though they play'd foul to win it, I fairly deserv'd to lose it. Take it I say, young man, you have the money and I have the warning. So! I've disposed of three rogues;
wou'd every honest man do as much, 'twou'd be a thinner meeting than it is.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Ah, Francis! here am I.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Ah, Master Sapling—I read your fortune in your face.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: It's all over: I'm done for; clean as the back of my hand; bare as a pick'd pigeon: every sous, be-gad!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: I guessed as much.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: And the fellows who pillag'd you are call'd Dipp, Spavin and Putty.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Even so; the tallow-chandler kindly help'd off my ready, the glazier condescended to put up with my phaeton, and the dealer did me the favour to relieve me of my horses.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: And who is to relieve you of your bill, Ma∣ster Sapling? the house must be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Right; there's a guinea a night for your bed.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P:
Oh, Sir, I can readily spare it all to you. As for my bill my wardrobe must pay that. I wish it would fit you, Sir, a worse will serve my turn.
But how did you know the names of these fellows? you are a stranger here as well as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Yes, but they made no stranger of me: why I took your seat.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: And succeeded to my luck, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: But I did not bear it quite so patiently.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: I wish you had been here. This gentleman has the prettiest method of perswasion you ever saw; he got his money back in a trice.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Got it back! for the love of pity tell me how.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Nothing so easy—but you'll observe my direc∣tions?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Punctually.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: And you'll strictly copy my receipt?

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: To a tittle; leave me alone for copying; I'm pretty well used to that in Pippin Alley.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: This is my nostrum; 'tis a sovereign medicine—furnish yourself with the fellow weapon of this: draw it resolutely and apply it manfully; you will find it work powerfully on the constitution of a rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: I thank you. Sir,—but it won't serve my turn: the remedy may be a good one in your hands, but in mine it would prove worse than the disease.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Well, my good Boy, sneak back into the kitchen, get a slice from off the spit, pluck off this puppily habit and take a place in the basket for Pippin's Alley—I'm going to look for Mr. Rivers, d'ye see; and when I come back, I'll go after the turf-gentlemen and recover your money—and if ever I find you in this place putting on the airs of a gentleman again, I'll not leave an ear upon your head to stick a pen behind.

SP.SPEAKER: SAPLING.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I was born in Pippin Alley, I was bred in Pippin Alley, and to Pippin Alley must return. There is more fatigue than I dream'd of in the character of a gentleman. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: I am ashamed to read it to you—take it how∣ever; in your transactions you may pass it to him as a money bill; I've drawn it in that form: 'tis a romantic fancy, but I am too apt to deal in such: I trust, however, I shall not repent any thing I do for Mr. Rivers.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I trust you never will—(reaas the note) “At sight hereof, I promise to surrender on demand, the heart, hand, and fortune of Maria Cheve∣ley.” Most generous of women! never blush for having saved an honest, though imprudent, man: this gay and innocent device, this new and unexpected surprise, will enhance the blessing and double his delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Haste then, dear Sir, and execute this giddy plot, before it is too late.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Fear nothing: he'll not depart, till he sees me.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: What, run to Ireland; retreat across the Da∣nube, and leave the field of battle to the foe? in∣glorious! of a certain, Frank, there's been some ugly cross of the jade in your pedigree, or you would not thus take rest and break the course.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I have given you my reason.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P:
There's no reason in the case; a gamester's ac∣tions never stoop to reason; do as I do, set it at defiance, or if you must use reason, use it as a courier, send it before you to announce your motions, never let it follow like a lagging foot∣boy at your back: you should have reason'd e'er
you shook the dice; I own you was a silly fellow to commence a gamester, but you are now as fit a person to continue one as any of the trade.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: When a man has out-liv'd his credit, he may resort to gaming, just as he may to methodism, when he has out-liv'd his principle; but he who carries a sound estate to the hazard-table is as much out of his way, as he who carries a sound head into the tabernacle.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: There you speak sense—O Revell, why will you abuse such parts?

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: I tell thee, Frank, thou art a fellow whom I love, I know not why, but there's a grace, a fa∣cility in thy nature which mightily becomes thee: be content; I'll do thee a service, I would not render any other man living.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: As how, dear Revel?

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Sooner than thou shalt sink, I'll take the blad∣ders upon which I swim and fit them to thy arms.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: This seems friendly, but be more explicit.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: I'll lend thee Issachar; I'll promote thee to my Jew, the ablest financier in Christendom.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Ridiculous! aad so let a mortgage canker out my whole estate; I'll sell it rather.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Mortgage your estate, mortgage the realm of Poland, mortgage the air you breathe, Issachar will raise money as a witch does wind: keep your estate and grant away your life, that's an incum∣brance you can soon pay off.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Well, Revell, fare you well, you have a ge∣nius to retrieve your fortune, I must pursue a plainer track; but have a care that your example does not ruin your country before your under∣standing can come to its assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Nay, Frank, now you grow as dull as a sen∣timental comedy; adieu! here lies my road; within there! (The door of the inner room is open'd, and discovers a large party at the gaming table.) Will you enter? No! nor give one parting look, one kind adieu? inexorable! hark, can you with∣stand that animating rattle?

LG.L: There sit the master-spirits of the age,
Fit to disturb the peace of all the world,
And rule it when tis wildest—have among you.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: There's a superior now; that's taste and pirit, a bold free stile of acting Oh! I could moralize, but 'tis too late.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter SUNDERLAND without being observ'd by RIVERS.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Ay, there he is, buried in thought;—when men of sense reflect upon their errors, 'tis to quit them; fools invent excuses for their follies and persist in 'em. 'Tis a romantic commission I am charged with, but Mrs. Cheveley does every thing after a manner of her own.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: So, Mr. Sunderland, I have expected you some time.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I see your chaise is waiting; are you resolute to leave us?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I only stay to give you these securities: I have left orders for the peremptory sale of my stud; my agent will pay the money into your hands, for which you'll credit me upon the back of these bonds; at my return from Ireland I shall put matters in a train for sinking the remainder. When you return to Mrs. Cheveley, bear her my ten∣derest wishes; say that I carry hence a heart, not more convicted of its own folly, than penetrated with her virtues: If 'twere in my power, I'd wish she shou'd forget me.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: I shall obey you; but before we part, allow me to accommodate you with a trifling sum for your occasions on the road;—I know I've stript you of your ready cash. (takes out his pocket-book.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, Sir, I had overlook'd that cir∣cumstance, and I accept your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: There, Sir, (presenting a bill inclos'd in a paper.) perhaps you will not like it the worse for having been in the possession of Mrs. Cheveley.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: The meanest things may be ennobled by Mrs. Cheveley:—shall I give you my acknowledgment?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: By no means; it will only take up time. Your most obedient. [Exit hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You are positively the most civil robber that ever exercis'd the profession; (puts up the bill.) if indeed it be your profession; for there is some∣thing in your proceedings, in your connection with Mrs. Cheveley, and through the progress of our acquaintance, which I can't unriddle. Mrs. Cheve∣ley! Oh, I could have borne all but loss of that too lovely woman! Madman that I was—Heyday!

DIV3.STAGE: [A scuffle is heard at the door between the WAITER and MAC CORMUCK.]

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Isn't it a coffee-house, pray you now? and what is a coffee-house but a public house?

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, but it is a club of gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P:
Well, and what is a club of gentlemen but a public company? and who am I but a gentleman?
and what is the fellow bothering about all this while to no purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: What is the matter? give the gentleman ad∣mission.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Sir, your obedient;—stand further off, I say;—what ails the fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You will excuse him, Sir;—no stranger is ad∣mitted here;—he is only doing his duty;—how∣ever, he shall not molest you:—leave the room. I will bear you harmless. [Exit Waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: A very civil pretty spoken gentleman, upon my conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You seem to have some earnest business in this place: what are your commands here pray?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, commands here! give the devil his due, that is in other hands; but under favour, I am in search of one Mr. Rivers, an unhappy idle young man, who is wasting a good estate in bad company; no offence I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: That is with Mr. Rivers;—what he might think in the case I won't take on me to say.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P:
We, that are his poor tenants in Ireland, have taken full as much offence at him, as he can at us;—rack, rack,—drain, drain—and here's the gulph that swallows it; (looking into the gaming room) damnation! there's a room full of 'em yon∣der,
hard at work. Oh, you're a precious set▪ blue ribbons, reds and greens! upon my soul it makes me blush, and that's no easy matter. Mercy be good unto me, how they swear! curse on the whole tribe of you, you're all so wicked, if the old one himself was to come amongst you, he'd be ashamed to sit down in your company.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You are not aware, perhaps, that you are rail∣ing against some of the first people in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay, but in faith they are the last I shou'd wish Mr. Rivers to be found with.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You wou'd not know him, probably, if you shoud see him.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Lack-a-day! he was a lad no thicker than my word, when he was at my house; by the same token he tumbled into a turf-pit; by my soul if I had known he wou'd have turn'd out such a game∣ster, I wou'd not have troubled myself to draw him out:—his father was a hearty little gentleman, and crack'd his bottle:—I fit a duel with the doctor, for saying he died of a drinking-bout at my house; the doctor out-liv'd the duel, but he lost his business for the folly of his opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Your name then is Mac Cormuck.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: That is my name sure enough; but how the devil did you know it?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Your wonder will cease, when I tell you, you talking to Mr. Rivers.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: You Mr. Rivers! well, you cannot say I have slander'd you behind your bak.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Your reproof has been so just, I've much more need to blush at it than you have—and now I call your person to my remembrance, tho' I was very young when you receiv'd us at your hospitable houe.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, I cannot crack of the hospitality of my poor cabbin; but I shou'd be sorry if you had ound it quite so hard to enter, as I did this of your'.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: And now tell me what may have brought you ever to England, Mr. Mac Cormuck?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Faith, Sir, in the first place business, and in the next, a little spice of curiosity, to take a peep her at our sister kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Well, Sir, and what do you think of us?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Why, I think you've got all the inheritance to yourselves, and that it would be but charity to throw us a rag of clothes to kiver our nakedness; by my soul, Mr. Rivers, it wou'd be for the honour of the family and a christian-like action into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I join with you heartily, Mr. Mac Cormuck, you speak my sentiments entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Indeed! I declare I cou'd not have believ'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Why so, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Faith, because hitherto we have been favour'd with little else from your hands, I think, but re∣ceipts for our rents, and regulations for raising them.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: That's true enough, but others have done the same; others, as well as I, have rais'd their Irish ents.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay, have they, and their Irish riots at the same time;—I wish to my soul you cou'd take a look at the family mansion at Castle-Rivers.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Is it gone much to decay.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Not at all, at all, there's no decay about it; your tenants have prevented that.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: How so; have they repair'd it then?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: No, faith, they've pull'd it down.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Hey-day! I've had no such intimation from my steward.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Why, that's not to be wonder'd at neither, for they knock'd him o' the head at the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: So much for your news, Mr. Mac Cormuck, which is melancholly enough; now for your business.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Why, I am thinking, 'twou'd be well done to renew that bit of a lease I hold under you at Shal∣linghorag, whereby I have but one life left in it, d'ye mind?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: 'Tis a wise precaution, and for the good of posterity.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Devil a care have I for posterity, so it lasts but my time: myself is all that is left of my posterity.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Put in your own life then, and all is safe.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: That's done already, you shall know, but I think with two stout fellows to bear me company, I may set accidents at defiance and last the longer.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS▪
SP.P: That indeed is a consideration that escaped me; now hear my proposal.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Ay, what's that? so it be in reason, I shall consent.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I am this instant setting off for Ireland.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: For Ireland? whuh!

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Will you bear me company?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P:
All the world thro', so you come to little Ire∣land at the end of it, by the soul of me; and you shall be as welcome as Saint Patrick's day, every hair of your head:—ah! we'll have merry doings
at Shallinghorag; what, you've forgot it now I warrant, blessing upon the sweet face of it! 'tis a lovely snug little cabbin of a place, with a handsome potatoe ground o' one hand of me, a fine convenient bog in my front, and a banging big mountain to shelter me at my back.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Come, Sir, description will but delay us; take this money bill, if you please, show it to any of the waiters, and they'll give you cash for it; in the meanwhile I will give some orders to my ser∣vants. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Let me see what's upon the face of it first. (reads.) At sight hereof—ay, ay, that's right; had it been one of our bills of Ballinasoe, good chance but it had been six months after; troth they're sometimes as long in bringing forth as a cow. (Revell enters.) Harkee, waiter, come hither, lad, come hither. (to Revell.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: What ails the man, do you mistake a gentleman for a waiter?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Faith, 'tis an easy blunder, your waiters are such gentlemen, how cou'd I tell but that your gentle∣men might be waiters? however, you may do my job for me, sarrow-a-bit the worse for being a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: What is your job?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Only give me cash for this money-bill, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Oh! it's a good one: it's at sight—what is it you grin at?

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: This is admirable!—pray, Sir, of whom had you this note?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Of one 'Squire Rivers. Oh! if it's not a good one, look you, I've no stake in it; that's his con∣cern.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir, the note's a very good one, and the drawer of the note, is, I dare say, very able to answer the contents, and you are a very obliging gentleman to give me the preference.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Oh! you're satisfied about it, are you? this is lucky.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: I understand it belongs to Mr. Rivers; I know him full well: this rouleau contains fifty guineas: you need not tell 'em; pay that to him and he'll be satisfied. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P:
Fifty guineas! 'tis a good big sum and lies in a mighty small compass. Ods my life, sure I have
made two or three little mistakes in this business; first, I should have asked the gentleman his name before we parted; secondly, I should have look'd at the bill before I chang'd it; thirdly—

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: The bill! the bill! give me the bill—what do you tell me, Mr. Sunderland? I'm all impatience!

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: I think so too; but I'm beforehand with you; there's your money. (giving the rouleau▪

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: What do you mean? give me the bill, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: The bill! why there you're out of reason, Mr. Rivers; would you have the bill and the money too?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: You terrfy me; have you parted with the bill?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Yes, faith, and I was terrified myself, for once he look'd as if he meant to boggle, you must know, but luckily I pass'd it off at last.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Distressful circumstance! whom did you give it to?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Why I did think of asking his name, but it was after he was gone.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: How could you be so insufferably careless not to read the bill before you put it out of your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Why 'twas an oversight; but pray now how came you not to read it yourself and stop the blunder in it's birth?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: O my unlucky stars! Sunderland, what shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: The note is evidently in a gentleman's hands by this circumstance of the rouleau: and it seems, whoever he is, he is gone away with it; probably to Mrs. Cheveley's, if he's acquainted with her; you must run thither immediately and pass the matter off as well as you can,

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I am asham'd to look her in the face—but come.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: By my conscience I shall follow him, though I neither know whither he is going nor what he is about. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P:
Mrs. Cheveley, I am happy in finding you at home, because in matters of negociation, dipatch
is the life of business, The world and you, Ma∣dam, are well informed of my habits in life; it is impossible to disguise that I have turned over a little cash in the course of play, and overturned it indeed; but I have luckily made a hit this morn∣ing that will set me up for ever; I have a paper in my hand, that will put me above envying any man's fortune in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir! and how am I concerned in it?

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Deeply, Madam; it is a note under your own hand; with your leave I'll read it—At sight hereof.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY
SP.P: Hold: I beseech you not to read it.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: It is at sight; I am the holder: will you dis∣charge it, or avow yourself a bankrupt?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: I need not tell you this was designed for an∣other: I am ashamed of my indiscretion; but you are a man of honour. In the name of wonder, how came the note into your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: I respect you for your spirit; I know your par∣tiality for my friend Rivers, and I scorn to dis∣guise any thing from you—Hark! I hear him at the door—In one word, there is a blunder in the business perfectly innocent on all sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: I'm satisfied—say nothing, but as I direct you.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Never fear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Your humble servant, Mr. Rivers! this is per∣fectly obliging; you are bound for Ireland, and I am happy in this opportunity of bidding you farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Madam, I—I—I—. Your servant, Mr. Re∣vell, I left a party of your friends, Sir, at the coffee-house who are impatient for your com∣pany—I dare not speak to her while he is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Mr. Revell is here, Sir, negociating a little business; his friends will readily excuse him. You will be kind enough, to tell 'em so.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I see he is the man; how shall I get him out of the room? (aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Rivers, you have charming weather for your journey.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Frank, don't you see your company is rather unseasonable? I know you hate to spoil sport.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Curse on your sport! it is my torment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: What does the gentleman say?

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Only to excuse his hasty departure to you; he is obliged to take his leave rather abruptly.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: No, Sir, I cannot go; to part from Mrs. Che∣veley thus, would be my death—may not I ask a moment's audience in private?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Speak your commands; this gentleman's my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I hope you do this only to punish me for my carelessness; I have lost a paper, Madam, of in∣estimable value.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Poor gentleman! and are you going to Ireland in search of it?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: No, Madam, I suspect that gentleman has got it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: A note, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I own it.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Well, you have got what you like better; fifty guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: 'Twas payable to bearer; you would not have the credit of the house impeach'd.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Dear Madam, do not torture me; Sunderland put it into my hands as a money-bill: in my confusion I passed it over to an Irish tenant; he with as little attention to Mr. Revell—The gentleman is now in your house; I beg I may call him in.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Save yourself that trouble. Ah! by my soul▪ and there's the very gentleman himself: come, Sir, surrender up the bill, or you and I must have a tustle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Revell, what shall we do now? we are likely to be stormed; I fear we must e'en sur∣render at discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Let me march out with the honours of love, and I'll evacuate the garrison. Thus let me give you joy. (Kisses her hand) And since I am not worthy to possess the prize myself, let me be∣stow it on a friend who is. (presents the note.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. CHEVELEY.
SP.P: Your gallantry becomes you.—What shall I say? O, Rivers! reformed as I perswade myself you truly are, you merit all that I can give. The worthless scrap is your's; you must conclude the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Thus on my knees I thank you; not in words, for love and gratitude stop those, but in the silent speakings of a heart, which is for ever and entirely your's.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Silent speakings! troth, if you spoke that aloud▪ you cou'd say no less.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: Joy, joy betide you both! may a long series of continued happiness spring from this auspicious moment!

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Alas! you know not what you do. I am a ruin'd man.

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: There I must interpose. You have an uncle, of whom it seems you've lost all memory; he is return'd from India, rich as your wishes can desire;—I# am he.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: Merciful heaven! my creditor my uncle!—This is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: I wou'd to fortune, all my creditors were of that sort?

SP.SPEAKER: SUNDERLAND.
SP.P: At my return I found you plung'd in a dis∣graceful practise;—I follow'd you from place to place; associated myself with you in your prodi∣galities, in your play. Your principle and your attachment to this lady saved you in my esteem;—your reformation is now I trust confirmed, and I re∣ceive you to my arms with joy.

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P: I blush at the recollection.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Oh! where is little Shallinghorag now?

SP.SPEAKER: RIVERS.
SP.P:
Fear nothing; since you think our demands have been too heavy, take it rent-free for your life, and in return administer my interests with more humanity and better fortune than your predecessor:—tell my needy tenants, they shall no longer be rack'd to pamper the carase of a race-horse,
and support the profligate excesses of a gaming table.

SP.SPEAKER: MAC CORMUCK.
SP.P: Now you are a noble genius! and were all absentees of your mind, we wou'd leave their estates untax'd for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: REVELL.
SP.P: Now, Rivers, prate against Newmarket if you dare. Many a good match have I seen made upon this turf, but never one so equal, so judicious as the present.
